Data 

data(bfi, package = "psych")

25 personality self report items taken from the International Personality Item Pool (ipip.ori.org) were included as part of the Synthetic Aperture Personality Assessment (SAPA) web based personality assessment project. The data from 2800 subjects are included here as a demonstration set for scale construction, factor analysis, and Item Response Theory analysis. Three additional demographic variables (sex, education, and age) are also included.

str(bfi)

add id 

bfi<-tibble::add_column(bfi, id=1:nrow(bfi))
var<-c(id=29,a=1:5,c=6:10,e=11:15,n=16:20,o=21:25)

create questionnaire object 

questionnaire<-Questionnaire(bfi,var)

compute factor mean 

data_mean<-questionnaire$ComputeMean()
str(data_mean)

The project analysis employs Item Response Theory (IRT), which can utilize the Generalized Rating Scale Model (GRM) to estimate item parameters (Rizopoulos, 2006). This model assumes that each item is associated with an underlying continuous variable (θ), which is related to the probability of responding to the item. The GRM model can be used to assess the difficulty and discrimination of items.

Reliability 

questionnaire$RunCfa()

Cronbach’s alpha 

questionnaire$Alpha()
#>     a     c     e     n     o 
#> 0.606 0.005 0.046 0.808 0.038

Composite reliability 

questionnaire$CR()
#>          a          c          e          n          o 
#> 0.61528221 0.04056654 0.11382210 0.81989304 0.09993916

Composite reliability is higher than 0.6 (Fornell & Larcker, 1981)。

Validity

Convergent validity 

questionnaire$AVE()
#>     a     c     e     n     o 
#> 0.350 0.372 0.403 0.481 0.245

Average Variance Extracted (AVE) is higher than 0.5 (Fornell & Larcker, 1981)。

Discriminant validity 

questionnaire$Discriminant_Validity()
#>       a    c    e    n    o
#> a  0.59   NA   NA   NA   NA
#> c  0.07 0.61   NA   NA   NA
#> e  0.30 0.18 0.63   NA   NA
#> n -0.13 0.25 0.04 0.69   NA
#> o  0.20 0.26 0.26 0.16 0.49

The Fornell-Larcker criterion is a widely used method for assessing discriminant validity(Fornell & Larcker, 1981). Its core principle is that the square root of the Average Variance Extracted (AVE) for each construct should be greater than the correlation coefficients between that construct and all other constructs

Construct validity 

questionnaire$Fitmeasures()
#>    chisq       df   pvalue      cfi      tli    rmsea     srmr 
#> 4165.467  265.000    0.000    0.782    0.754    0.078    0.073

References

Fornell, C., & Larcker, D. F. (1981). Evaluating Structural Equation Models with Unobservable Variables and Measurement Error. Journal of Marketing Research, 18(1), 39. https://doi.org/10.2307/3151312
Rizopoulos, D. (2006). Ltm : An r Package for Latent Variable Modeling and Item Response Theory Analyses. Journal of Statistical Software, 17(5). https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v017.i05
